ourMission.title: Our Mission
ourMission.content: At Kolr, we believe that color is one of the most powerful tools in design and visual communication. Our mission is to democratize access to professional-grade color tools, making sophisticated color theory principles accessible to everyone—from seasoned designers to creative beginners. We strive to bridge the gap between artistic intuition and technical precision, empowering creators to make informed color decisions that elevate their work.

theStory.title: The Story Behind Kolr
theStory.content: Kolr was born out of a simple frustration: existing color tools were either too complex for beginners or too limited for professionals. As designers ourselves, we spent countless hours manually extracting colors from inspiration images, testing contrast ratios, and experimenting with different harmony rules. We knew there had to be a better way.
theStory.content2: In 2024, we set out to create a tool that would combine the power of advanced color algorithms with the simplicity of modern mobile design. We studied color theory extensively, from Josef Albers' groundbreaking work on color interaction to modern WCAG accessibility standards. The result is Kolr—a comprehensive color toolkit that fits in your pocket.
theStory.content3: What started as a simple photo-to-palette extractor has evolved into a complete color design ecosystem. Today, Kolr serves thousands of designers, artists, photographers, and color enthusiasts worldwide, helping them create harmonious color schemes for everything from brand identities to interior design projects.

understanding-color-theory-basics.title: Understanding Color Theory Basics: A Complete Guide for Designers
understanding-color-theory-basics.excerpt: Master the fundamentals of color theory, from the color wheel to primary, secondary, and tertiary colors. Learn how colors interact and create visual harmony.
understanding-color-theory-basics.content:
What is Color Theory?

Color theory is the science and art of using color. It explains how humans perceive color and provides guidance for creating effective color combinations. Understanding color theory is essential for any designer, artist, or creative professional working with visual media.

The Color Wheel

The color wheel is the fundamental tool of color theory. First developed by Sir Isaac Newton in 1666, it organizes colors in a circle to show relationships between primary, secondary, and tertiary colors.

Primary Colors

Primary colors are the foundation of all other colors. In traditional color theory (used in painting), the primary colors are red, yellow, and blue. These colors cannot be created by mixing other colors together.

Secondary Colors

Secondary colors are created by mixing two primary colors:

  • Orange = Red + Yellow
  • Green = Yellow + Blue
  • Purple = Blue + Red

Tertiary Colors

Tertiary colors result from mixing a primary color with an adjacent secondary color. Examples include red-orange, yellow-green, and blue-violet. These colors add nuance and depth to your palette.

Color Properties

Every color has three main properties that define its appearance:

Hue

Hue is the pure color itself—what we commonly call 'color.' Red, blue, green, and yellow are all different hues. Hue is determined by the wavelength of light.

Saturation (Chroma)

Saturation refers to the intensity or purity of a color. A highly saturated color is vivid and bright, while a desaturated color appears muted or grayish. Reducing saturation creates softer, more subtle tones.

Value (Brightness)

Value describes how light or dark a color is. Adding white to a color creates a tint (lighter value), while adding black creates a shade (darker value). Value is crucial for creating contrast and visual hierarchy.

Understanding Color Relationships

Colors don't exist in isolation—they interact with each other. Understanding these relationships helps you create harmonious and effective color schemes.

Warm vs Cool Colors

Colors are often categorized as warm or cool:

  • Warm colors (red, orange, yellow) are energetic and advance visually
  • Cool colors (blue, green, purple) are calming and recede visually

Using warm and cool colors strategically can create depth, mood, and emphasis in your designs.

Complementary Colors

Complementary colors sit opposite each other on the color wheel (like red and green, or blue and orange). When placed together, they create maximum contrast and vibration, making each color appear more intense.

Practical Applications

Understanding color theory helps you make informed design decisions. Use the color wheel to create balanced palettes, leverage contrast for emphasis, and understand how colors will interact before implementing them in your projects.

Tools for Color Theory

Digital tools like Kolr make it easy to apply color theory principles. Our color harmony explorer helps you generate complementary, analogous, and triadic schemes automatically, while our contrast checker ensures your color choices meet accessibility standards.

By mastering these color theory basics, you'll have a strong foundation for creating beautiful, effective color palettes for any design project.

creating-accessible-color-palettes.title: Creating Accessible Color Palettes: WCAG Guidelines and Best Practices
creating-accessible-color-palettes.excerpt: Learn how to design color palettes that everyone can use. Comprehensive guide to WCAG contrast ratios, color blindness considerations, and accessibility testing.
creating-accessible-color-palettes.content:
Why Color Accessibility Matters

Approximately 1 in 12 men and 1 in 200 women have some form of color vision deficiency. Additionally, users with low vision, older adults, and people using devices in bright sunlight all benefit from accessible color choices. Creating accessible color palettes isn't just about compliance—it's about inclusive design that works for everyone.

Understanding WCAG Contrast Standards

The Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) provide specific contrast ratio requirements for text and interactive elements.

WCAG AA Standards (Minimum)

  • Normal text: Minimum contrast ratio of 4.5:1
  • Large text (18pt+ or 14pt+ bold): Minimum contrast ratio of 3:1
  • UI components: Minimum contrast ratio of 3:1 for interface elements

WCAG AAA Standards (Enhanced)

  • Normal text: Minimum contrast ratio of 7:1
  • Large text: Minimum contrast ratio of 4.5:1

Meeting AAA standards provides the best readability and is recommended for text-heavy applications, educational content, and interfaces used by older adults.

Choosing Accessible Color Combinations

High Contrast is Key

The most reliable way to ensure accessibility is to use high contrast between text and backgrounds. Dark text on light backgrounds or light text on dark backgrounds typically work best.

Don't Rely on Color Alone

Never use color as the only way to convey information. Always pair color with text labels, icons, patterns, or other visual indicators. For example, don't just show errors in red—also include an error icon and descriptive text.

Test with Actual Tools

Use tools like Kolr's contrast checker to verify your color combinations meet WCAG standards before implementing them. Testing early in the design process saves time and prevents accessibility issues.

Color Blindness Considerations

Different types of color vision deficiency affect how people perceive colors:

  • Protanopia/Deuteranopia (red-green color blindness): Difficulty distinguishing reds and greens
  • Tritanopia (blue-yellow color blindness): Difficulty distinguishing blues and yellows
  • Achromatopsia (total color blindness): Rare condition where no colors are perceived

Safe Color Combinations

Some color combinations work well for most types of color blindness:

  • Blue and orange
  • Blue and yellow (but ensure sufficient contrast)
  • Dark colors with white or light backgrounds
  • Avoid red-green combinations without additional indicators

Practical Tips for Accessible Palettes

1. Start with Grayscale

Design your interface in grayscale first to ensure your information hierarchy works without color. Then add color to enhance, not replace, the existing clarity.

2. Use Sufficient Color Contrast

Aim for at least 4.5:1 contrast for body text. For critical elements like call-to-action buttons, aim even higher.

3. Provide Multiple Visual Cues

Combine color with shape, position, text labels, and icons to convey meaning.

4. Test Your Designs

Use color blindness simulators and contrast checkers throughout your design process. Get feedback from users with different types of color vision.

5. Document Your Decisions

Create a style guide that documents which color combinations meet accessibility standards and how they should be used in your product.

Tools and Resources

Kolr's contrast checker makes it easy to verify WCAG compliance in real-time. Simply input your foreground and background colors to see if they meet AA and AAA standards for different text sizes.

By prioritizing accessibility in your color palette choices, you create designs that are beautiful, functional, and inclusive for all users.

color-psychology-in-design.title: Color Psychology in Design: How Colors Influence Emotions and Behavior
color-psychology-in-design.excerpt: Discover how colors affect human psychology and behavior. Learn to choose colors that evoke the right emotions and support your design goals.
color-psychology-in-design.content:
The Power of Color Psychology

Colors do more than make designs look attractive—they trigger emotional responses, influence perceptions, and even affect behavior. Understanding color psychology helps you make strategic color choices that support your design objectives and connect with your audience on a deeper level.

Common Color Associations

Red: Energy, Passion, Urgency

Red is the most stimulating color. It increases heart rate and creates a sense of urgency. In design, red is effective for:

  • Call-to-action buttons (especially for sales and urgent actions)
  • Highlighting important information or warnings
  • Food and beverage brands (stimulates appetite)
  • Energetic and bold brand identities

Caution: Red can also signify danger or error. Use it thoughtfully to avoid creating unintended stress or anxiety.

Blue: Trust, Calm, Professionalism

Blue is the most universally liked color. It evokes feelings of trust, stability, and calm. Blue is ideal for:

  • Financial services and healthcare (builds trust)
  • Technology companies (suggests innovation and reliability)
  • Corporate and professional contexts
  • Creating calming, peaceful environments

Caution: Too much blue can feel cold or impersonal. Balance it with warmer accent colors.

Green: Growth, Nature, Health

Green represents nature, growth, and renewal. It's associated with health, sustainability, and prosperity. Use green for:

  • Environmental and sustainability brands
  • Health and wellness products
  • Financial growth and money-related contexts
  • Success indicators (like confirmation messages)

Yellow: Optimism, Happiness, Energy

Yellow is the brightest color and captures attention quickly. It conveys optimism, creativity, and warmth. Yellow works well for:

  • Highlighting important information
  • Creative and playful brands
  • Calls-to-action in moderation
  • Children's products

Caution: Pure bright yellow can be difficult to read and overwhelming in large doses. Use it as an accent color.

Orange: Enthusiasm, Creativity, Affordability

Orange combines red's energy with yellow's happiness. It's friendly, cheerful, and inviting. Orange is effective for:

  • Call-to-action buttons (less aggressive than red)
  • Budget-friendly brands
  • Creative and artistic contexts
  • Expressing enthusiasm and excitement

Purple: Luxury, Creativity, Spirituality

Purple has historically been associated with royalty and luxury. It also suggests creativity and imagination. Use purple for:

  • Premium and luxury products
  • Beauty and cosmetics
  • Creative and artistic brands
  • Spiritual or mystical themes

Black: Sophistication, Power, Elegance

Black conveys sophistication, luxury, and authority. It's timeless and creates strong contrast. Black works well for:

  • High-end and luxury brands
  • Creating visual hierarchy and emphasis
  • Modern, minimalist designs
  • Professional and formal contexts

White: Purity, Simplicity, Cleanliness

White represents purity, cleanliness, and simplicity. It's essential for creating breathing room in designs. Use white for:

  • Healthcare and medical contexts
  • Minimalist and modern designs
  • Creating contrast and emphasis
  • Technology and innovation brands

Cultural Considerations

Color meanings vary significantly across cultures. For example:

  • White symbolizes purity in Western cultures but mourning in some Eastern cultures
  • Red means luck and prosperity in China but can signify danger in Western contexts
  • Yellow represents courage in Japan but can mean cowardice in some Western contexts

Always research your target audience's cultural context when choosing colors for international products.

Combining Colors for Emotional Impact

Single colors create specific emotions, but color combinations amplify or modify these effects:

  • Blue + Orange: Professional yet friendly
  • Black + Gold: Luxury and elegance
  • Green + Brown: Natural and organic
  • Purple + Pink: Creative and playful

Practical Application

When choosing colors for your project:

  1. Define your goals: What emotions do you want to evoke?
  2. Know your audience: What colors resonate with them?
  3. Consider context: Where and how will users experience your design?
  4. Test and iterate: Use A/B testing to validate your color choices

Beyond Trends

While color trends come and go, color psychology remains constant. Focus on choosing colors that authentically represent your brand and resonate with your audience, rather than simply following the latest design trends.

By understanding color psychology, you can create designs that not only look beautiful but also effectively communicate your message and connect with your audience on an emotional level.

mastering-color-harmonies.title: Mastering Color Harmonies: From Complementary to Tetradic Schemes
mastering-color-harmonies.excerpt: Complete guide to color harmony rules. Learn when and how to use complementary, analogous, triadic, and tetradic color schemes for stunning designs.
mastering-color-harmonies.content:
What Are Color Harmonies?

Color harmonies are combinations of colors that are aesthetically pleasing and create visual balance. Based on the color wheel, these tried-and-true formulas help designers create cohesive palettes that work well together. Understanding color harmonies takes the guesswork out of color selection.

Monochromatic Harmony

What It Is

Monochromatic color schemes use variations of a single hue by changing its saturation and brightness. This creates palettes with different tints, shades, and tones of one color.

When to Use It

  • Creating sophisticated, cohesive designs
  • Emphasizing content over color
  • Minimalist and elegant aesthetics
  • When you need a safe, professional palette

Pros and Cons

Pros: Easy to create, always harmonious, sophisticated look
Cons: Can lack visual interest, may feel monotonous

Tips

  • Ensure sufficient contrast between values for readability
  • Use texture and typography to add visual interest
  • Consider adding a neutral (black, white, gray) for depth

Analogous Harmony

What It Is

Analogous schemes use colors that sit next to each other on the color wheel, typically three colors (like blue, blue-green, and green).

When to Use It

  • Creating natural, harmonious designs
  • Nature-inspired palettes
  • Designs that need to feel cohesive and calm
  • Gradients and backgrounds

Pros and Cons

Pros: Naturally harmonious, rich and nuanced, easy on the eyes
Cons: Low contrast, needs careful hierarchy

Tips

  • Choose one color as dominant
  • Use the other colors as accents
  • Add a neutral or complementary accent for emphasis

Complementary Harmony

What It Is

Complementary schemes use colors opposite each other on the color wheel (like blue and orange, or red and green).

When to Use It

  • Creating high contrast and visual impact
  • Making elements stand out
  • Energetic, bold designs
  • Call-to-action elements

Pros and Cons

Pros: Maximum contrast, vibrant and eye-catching, creates depth
Cons: Can be overwhelming if overused, challenging to balance

Tips

  • Use one color as dominant and the other as accent
  • Desaturate one or both colors for subtlety
  • Avoid using pure complementary colors in equal amounts
  • Use tints and shades to create variations

Split-Complementary Harmony

What It Is

Split-complementary uses a base color plus the two colors adjacent to its complement. For example, blue with yellow-orange and red-orange (instead of pure orange).

When to Use It

  • More nuanced than complementary
  • When you need contrast without intensity
  • Balanced, interesting palettes

Pros and Cons

Pros: Good contrast with more options, easier to balance than complementary
Cons: More complex to manage

Triadic Harmony

What It Is

Triadic schemes use three colors equally spaced around the color wheel (like red, yellow, and blue—the primary colors—or orange, green, and purple).

When to Use It

  • Vibrant, balanced designs
  • Playful and dynamic aesthetics
  • When you need variety with harmony
  • Children's products and creative projects

Pros and Cons

Pros: Vibrant, balanced, versatile
Cons: Can be overwhelming, requires careful balance

Tips

  • Let one color dominate
  • Use the other two as accents
  • Consider using tints and shades to soften intensity

Tetradic (Double-Complementary) Harmony

What It Is

Tetradic schemes use four colors arranged into two complementary pairs. This forms a rectangle or square on the color wheel.

When to Use It

  • Rich, complex palettes
  • When you need many color options
  • Experienced designers comfortable with complexity

Pros and Cons

Pros: Most variety, rich and complex, many options
Cons: Hardest to balance, can easily become chaotic

Tips

  • Choose one dominant color
  • Balance warm and cool colors
  • Use neutrals to give the eye rest
  • Test extensively before finalizing

Choosing the Right Harmony

Consider these factors when selecting a color harmony:

  • Brand identity: Does it match your brand personality?
  • Project goals: What emotion or action do you want to inspire?
  • Audience: What will resonate with your users?
  • Context: Where will the design be used?
  • Complexity: How much visual interest do you need?

Tools for Creating Harmonies

Kolr's color harmony explorer automatically generates harmonious palettes based on these principles. Simply choose a base color and select your desired harmony type to instantly see complementary, analogous, triadic, and other schemes.

By mastering these color harmonies, you'll have a systematic approach to creating beautiful, balanced color palettes for any design project.

extracting-colors-from-photos.title: Extracting Colors from Photos: Techniques and Best Practices
extracting-colors-from-photos.excerpt: Learn how to extract perfect color palettes from photographs. Tips for choosing source images, analyzing dominant colors, and creating usable design palettes.
extracting-colors-from-photos.content:
Why Extract Colors from Photos?

Photographs contain naturally harmonious color combinations created by nature, lighting, and real-world contexts. Extracting colors from photos is an excellent way to create authentic, balanced palettes for your design projects. Whether you're designing a website, creating a brand identity, or working on illustration, photo-based palettes provide instant inspiration and proven color harmony.

Choosing the Right Source Image

Look for Images with Clear Color Stories

The best source images have a clear color narrative. Look for photos with:

  • 3-5 distinct, well-represented colors
  • Good lighting (not overexposed or too dark)
  • Intentional composition
  • Colors that reflect the mood you want to convey

Consider Your Project Context

Match your source image to your project goals:

  • Nature photos: Organic, calming palettes
  • Urban scenes: Modern, edgy combinations
  • Food photography: Appetizing, warm tones
  • Fashion: Trendy, curated color stories
  • Art and interiors: Sophisticated, intentional palettes

Avoid Common Pitfalls

  • Too many colors: Busy images create muddled palettes
  • Poor lighting: Results in muddy, inaccurate colors
  • Heavy filters: Can create unrealistic color relationships
  • Low resolution: May not provide accurate color data

Understanding Dominant vs. Accent Colors

Dominant Colors

These are the colors that appear most frequently in the image. They typically form the background or main elements. In your design, dominant colors should be used for:

  • Backgrounds
  • Large sections or containers
  • Primary UI elements

Accent Colors

Accent colors appear less frequently but catch the eye—like a red flower in a green field. Use accent colors for:

  • Call-to-action buttons
  • Important highlights
  • Interactive elements
  • Creating visual interest

Extraction Techniques

Automatic Extraction

Tools like Kolr use sophisticated algorithms to identify the most significant colors in an image. These tools analyze:

  • Color frequency
  • Spatial distribution
  • Perceptual importance
  • Color clustering

Manual Selection

Sometimes you'll want to manually pick specific colors from an image rather than using automatic extraction. This works well when:

  • You want to emphasize a particular element
  • The automatic extraction misses a key color
  • You're building a palette around one hero color

Refining Your Extracted Palette

Adjust for Digital Use

Colors in photos may need adjustment for screen use:

  • Brighten dark colors: Photos often contain very dark values that don't work well as UI colors
  • Increase saturation: Photos can be slightly desaturated; boost saturation for more vibrant UI elements
  • Adjust for contrast: Ensure your palette has sufficient contrast for accessibility

Create Color Variations

Extend your extracted palette by creating:

  • Tints: Add white to create lighter versions (for backgrounds, hover states)
  • Shades: Add black to create darker versions (for text, depth)
  • Tones: Add gray to create muted versions (for disabled states, secondary elements)

Test in Context

Always test your extracted palette in your actual design:

  • Apply colors to real UI components
  • Check readability and contrast
  • Verify the mood matches your goals
  • Get feedback from others

Common Use Cases

Brand Identity

Extract colors from photos that represent your brand values—nature photos for eco-brands, city scenes for urban products, etc.

Web Design

Use photo extraction to create cohesive color schemes that match header images or hero photography on your site.

Presentation Design

Extract colors from presentation images to create matching slide backgrounds, text colors, and accent elements.

Product Design

Draw inspiration from product photography or lifestyle images to create UI themes that feel authentic and connected to the physical product.

Using Kolr for Photo Extraction

Kolr makes photo extraction effortless:

  1. Upload your image or use your device camera
  2. Automatic analysis identifies the 5 most important colors
  3. Copy hex codes with one tap for use in your design tools
  4. Save to your gallery for future reference

You can also use Kolr's web-based image extractor tool to experiment with different photos and immediately see the resulting palettes.

Best Practices Summary

  • Choose images with clear, intentional color stories
  • Look for photos with good lighting and 3-5 distinct colors
  • Understand the difference between dominant and accent colors
  • Adjust extracted colors for digital use and accessibility
  • Create variations (tints, shades, tones) for a complete palette
  • Always test your palette in the actual design context

By mastering the art of color extraction from photos, you'll never run out of palette inspiration. Real-world imagery provides endless combinations that are naturally balanced and visually appealing.
